questions.question: What is the primary goal of DevOps culture?
options: To eliminate the operations team
To break down silos between development and operations teams
To focus only on automation tools
To replace developers with operations engineers
questions.explanation: DevOps culture emphasizes collaboration and communication between development and operations teams to improve the software delivery process.

questions.question: Which principle is a core value of DevOps?
options: Working in isolation
Blaming others for failures
Continuous improvement and learning from failures
Avoiding feedback loops
questions.explanation: DevOps promotes a culture of continuous improvement, where teams learn from failures and constantly optimize processes.

questions.question: What is the purpose of a Version Control System (VCS)?
options: To compile code automatically
To track changes to code over time and manage different versions
To deploy applications to production
To monitor application performance
questions.explanation: Version Control Systems track changes to files over time, allowing teams to collaborate, revert to previous versions, and manage code history.

questions.question: In Git, what does the 'git merge' command do?
options: Deletes a branch
Creates a new repository
Combines changes from different branches
Pushes code to a remote repository
questions.explanation: The 'git merge' command integrates changes from one branch into another, typically merging a feature branch into the main branch.

questions.question: What is a 'pull request' in Git workflows?
options: A request to download code from a repository
A proposal to merge changes from one branch into another for review
A command to update the local repository
A way to delete remote branches
questions.explanation: A pull request is a mechanism for developers to notify team members that they have completed a feature and request code review before merging.

questions.question: What is the benefit of using Agile methodologies in DevOps planning?
options: It eliminates the need for testing
It enables iterative development with frequent releases and feedback
It removes the need for documentation
It focuses solely on infrastructure management
questions.explanation: Agile methodologies support DevOps by enabling teams to work in short iterations, receive feedback quickly, and adapt to changing requirements.

questions.question: What is the primary goal of Continuous Integration?
options: Automatically deploy to production
Frequently integrate code changes into a shared repository
Eliminate the need for testing
Remove the need for branches
questions.explanation: Continuous Integration aims to detect integration issues early by frequently merging code changes and running automated tests.

questions.question: Which tool is commonly used for Continuous Integration?
options: Docker
Jenkins
Kubernetes
Terraform
questions.explanation: Jenkins is a popular open-source automation server widely used for implementing Continuous Integration pipelines.

questions.question: What should happen when a CI build fails?
options: Ignore it and continue with new commits
The team should be notified and the issue should be fixed immediately
Wait until the end of the sprint to fix it
Disable the CI pipeline
questions.explanation: When a CI build fails, it's critical to notify the team immediately and prioritize fixing the issue to maintain code quality and integration.

questions.question: What is a key practice in Continuous Integration?
options: Committing code once per month
Running automated tests with every code integration
Manually testing all changes
Deploying directly to production without testing
questions.explanation: Running automated tests with every integration is essential in CI to catch bugs early and ensure code quality.

questions.question: What is Continuous Delivery?
options: Automatically deploying every change to production
Ensuring code is always in a deployable state and can be released at any time
Delivering hardware to data centers continuously
Writing code without any testing
questions.explanation: Continuous Delivery ensures that code is always in a releasable state through automated testing and build processes, though deployment is still a manual decision.

questions.question: What differentiates Continuous Delivery from Continuous Deployment?
options: Continuous Delivery deploys automatically, Continuous Deployment requires manual approval
Continuous Delivery requires manual approval to deploy, Continuous Deployment is fully automated
They are the same thing
Continuous Delivery doesn't use automation
questions.explanation: Continuous Delivery keeps code deployment-ready but requires manual approval, while Continuous Deployment automatically deploys all changes that pass tests.

questions.question: Which practice is essential for Continuous Delivery?
options: Manual testing only
Automated testing and deployment pipelines
Infrequent code commits
Avoiding version control
questions.explanation: Automated testing and deployment pipelines are crucial for Continuous Delivery to ensure code can be released reliably at any time.

questions.question: In Continuous Deployment, when does code get deployed to production?
options: Once a week during maintenance windows
Automatically after passing all automated tests
Only when manually triggered by a manager
At the end of each sprint
questions.explanation: Continuous Deployment automatically releases code to production as soon as it passes all stages of the automated testing pipeline.

questions.question: What is a prerequisite for implementing Continuous Deployment?
options: Manual testing procedures
Comprehensive automated test coverage
Monthly release cycles
Separate development and production environments only
questions.explanation: Continuous Deployment requires comprehensive automated tests to ensure that code deployed automatically is of high quality and won't break production.

questions.question: What is Infrastructure as Code (IaC)?
options: Writing application code for infrastructure teams
Managing and provisioning infrastructure through machine-readable configuration files
Manually configuring servers through GUI
Coding only in infrastructure-specific languages
questions.explanation: Infrastructure as Code is the practice of managing infrastructure using configuration files, enabling version control, automation, and consistency.

questions.question: Which tool is commonly used for Infrastructure as Code?
options: Microsoft Word
Terraform
Photoshop
Excel
questions.explanation: Terraform is a popular IaC tool that allows you to define and provision infrastructure using declarative configuration files.

questions.question: What is a key benefit of using Infrastructure as Code?
options: It requires more manual intervention
Infrastructure can be version-controlled and reproduced consistently
It only works on physical servers
It eliminates the need for monitoring
questions.explanation: IaC allows infrastructure to be version-controlled, making it easy to track changes, reproduce environments, and ensure consistency across deployments.

questions.question: What does 'idempotent' mean in the context of Infrastructure as Code?
options: Running the same configuration multiple times produces the same result
Each run creates a new infrastructure instance
Configuration files cannot be reused
Infrastructure changes randomly with each execution
questions.explanation: Idempotent operations in IaC mean that applying the same configuration multiple times will result in the same infrastructure state, preventing unintended changes.

questions.question: What does 'shift left' mean in DevOps?
options: Moving team members to different departments
Incorporating testing and security earlier in the development process
Delaying testing until after deployment
Shifting work to offshore teams
questions.explanation: 'Shift left' refers to moving testing, security, and quality assurance earlier in the software development lifecycle to catch issues sooner and reduce costs.
